sentences.sentence: By Jock Finlayson and Steven GlobermanOver the past few months there's been a big increase in Canadian media coverage of the dramatic surge in "temporary" immigration(https://financialpost.com/tag/immigration/) - that is, of non-permanent residents (NPRs), including international students and foreigners here on various work visas - and the impact that has had on rental housing and government services.

But what about the link between NPRs and the labour market performance of permanent immigrants?The Trudeau government plans to boost Canada's labour force and grow the economy through high levels of permanent immigration, which is on track to reach 500,000 per year by the middle of this decade.
Less than 10 years ago, it was running at barely half that.Such a strategy depends crucially on new permanent immigrants' ability to find jobs and earn decent incomes.
To this end, increasing the number of NPRs enlarges the pool of potential applicants for permanent residence who have either education or employment experience in this country.

We find in our new study(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/enhancing-the-labour-market-outcomes-of-immigrants-to-canada) for the Fraser Institute that applicants who do have such experience in Canada are more likely to make an above-average contribution to economic growth than applicants who don't have it.

In brief, NPRs will likely become more productive permanent immigrants than newcomers who were never NPRs.Beyond education and work experience, a sizable body of research highlights how important proficiency(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/36-28-0001/2023001/article/00002-eng.htm) in either of Canada's official languages is to the labour market success of immigrants.
To this end, the selection criteria for permanent residents should give more weight to language proficiency than it currently does.

And the government could increase funding for language training and other post-landing services for new permanent residents, many of whom struggle to adapt to life in Canada.Research also shows that younger immigrants generally have better labour market outcomes than older ones, which suggests the government should give greater weight to an applicant's age in the permanent resident selection process.Governments could also relax professional licensing and other restrictions that currently prevent even immigrants with education and training of a quality and standard broadly equivalent to their Canadian-born counterparts from working in fields such as engineering and health care.
Professional and occupational licensing and certification are provincial government responsibilities, and some provinces are taking steps to reduce unnecessary barriers to occupational entry.

Still, more needs to be done to address these types of impediments to the labour market success of immigrants - without, of course, jeopardizing the quality of such services that Canadians are used to.Finally, one note of caution.

The federal government recently announced a potentially important set of modifications to the criteria used to select permanent residents under the Express Entry system, which expedites applications by skilled workers.
The modifications will allow Canada to issue invitations to prospective residents with specific skills and training.

While it's too early to judge the effects of this policy change, there may be a risk in giving a preference to applicants with very specific skills that are currently in demand while necessarily de-emphasizing more general "human capital" indicators, such as formal educational attainment and language ability.

A work force endowed with high levels of general human capital rather than more specific occupational skills may be more capable of undertaking the continuous education and retraining that can help workers adapt to changes in technology and workplace conditions and practices.The climate war heating up the bestsellers list(https://financialpost.com/opinion/climate-war-heating-up-bestsellers-list)Improve public health by swapping Big Tobacco for Big Vape(https://financialpost.com/opinion/improve-public-health-swap-big-tobacco-vape)Progress in economics isn't like progress in vaccines but it helps(https://financialpost.com/opinion/progress-economics-vaccines-helps)There is no question the federal government and governments across Canada can do more to improve the prospects of permanent immigrants and their contributions to the Canadian economy.Jock Finlayson and Steven Globerman, senior fellows at the Fraser Institute, are co-authors of the just-released "Enhancing the labour market outcomes of immigrants to Canada(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/enhancing-the-labour-market-outcomes-of-immigrants-to-canada)."
@COPYRIGHT=© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
